en: WHO Report Says COVID Cases Decline, Except in Americas, Africa
sna: Chinyorwa Chezvakabuda Mutsvakurudzo Che WHO Chinoti Vanhu Vari Kubatwa neCOVID Hwoderera, Kunze Kwenyika dzemudunhu reAmerica, Africa
mt0: <pad> The WHO report said the number of people infected with COVID had declined, except for countries in the Americas, Asia and Africa.</s>

en: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that the number of newly reported coronavirus cases and deaths globally continued to fall in the last week, continuing a decline that began in March.
sna: Sangano rinoona nezvehutano pasi rose reWorld Health Organization rakati neChitatu kuti huwandu hwevanhu vari kubatwa kekutanda nedenda re coronavirus nendufu dzacho pasi rose dzakaramba dzichidzikira svondo rakapera, richiteedzera kuderera kwakatanga munaKurume.
mt0: <pad> The World Health Organization said on Wednesday that the number of coronavirus cases and deaths worldwide continued to decline last week, reflecting a fall in cases that began in March.</s>

en: In its weekly report on the pandemic, the U.N. health agency said there were about 3.8 million new infections and more than 15,000 deaths last week, a 17% and 3% drop on the week respectively.
sna: Muzvinyorwa zvetsvakurudzo dzaro dzinobuda svondo rega rega, sangano iri, riri chikamu chemubatanidzwa wenyika dzepasi rese chichiona nezvehutano rakati kune vanhu vangasvika mamiriyoni matatu nezviuru mazana masere vakabatwa nechirwere ichi kekutanga uyewo nendufu dzinodarika zviuru gumi nezvishanu svondo rakapfuura, kuderera kwezvikamu gumi nezvinomwe kubva muzana pane vakarwara nechirwere ichi kekutanga, nekudererawo wezvikamu zvitatu kubva muzana kwendufu musvondo irori.
mt0: <pad> In its weekly report, the organization, a member of the World Health Organization, said there were nearly 3 million first-time cases and over 15 000 deaths last week, a reduction of 17 percent in first-time cases and a reduction of 3 percent in deaths this week.</s>

en: But those figures are believed to be a significant underestimate of COVID-19's true toll as increasing numbers of countries abandon widespread testing and surveillance.
sna: Asi huwandu uhwu hwunofungidzirwa kuti hwakanyanya kuderedzwa zvachose kwekurwarisa nekuuraya kuri kuita COVID-19 sezvo nyika dziri kungoramba dzichiwedzera pahuwandu hwadzo dzakanda pasi tsika yekuongorora ropa revanhu uyezve nekuronda nekuongorora kaupararira kwedenda iri.
mt0: <pad> But this number is believed to be the most drastic decrease in the total fatality and infection rate of COVID-19 as countries continue to increase their numbers of people testing for the virus and monitoring and tracking the spread of the disease.</s>

en: Still, WHO noted that cases rose by about a third in Africa and 13% in the Americas.
sna: Zvakadaro, WHO yakaona kuti hurwere hwakawedzera nechikamu chimwe chete kubva muzvitatu muAfrica uyewo nezvikamu gumi nezvitatu kubva muzana munyika dziri mudunhu reAmerica.
mt0: <pad> However, the WHO has found that the disease has increased by one-third in Africa and by 13 percent in the Americas.</s>

en: There was also a nearly 70% jump in deaths reported in India, although that was attributed to delayed reporting rather than a recent surge of disease.
sna: Pakavawo nekusvetuka chaiko kwendufu dzakaziviswa vezvehutano muIndia, kunyangwe hazvo izvi zvakanzi kwaiva kunonoka kutaurira vezvehutano pamusoro pendufu, kusati kuri kuwedzera kwedenda.
mt0: <pad> There was also a real flu outbreak reported by the health ministry in India, although this was said to be a delayed notification of the health ministry about the flu, before the outbreak became a pandemic.</s>

en: Last week, authorities in South Africa said they had noted an uptick in COVID-19 cases attributable to the BA.4 mutant of omicron, although they said it was too early to tell if that would result in a significant new wave of disease.
sna: Svondo rakadarika, vakuru muSouth Africa vakati vakaona kuti pakaita kusimukira kwevanhu vanedenda reCOVID-19 zvinzi zvaibva kumhando yechirwere inonzi BA.4 iyo inonzi yakabukira kubva mu omicron, iyo inoratidza kuti ine hukasha hwekupararira nekukurumidza kudarika omicron, kunyangwe hazvo pasati pava nenguva yakakwana yekuongorora kuti izvi zvaizoreva kuti paizova nekupararira kutsva kwedenda iri kune mutsindo.
mt0: <pad> Last Saturday, South African officials said they had identified a new outbreak of COVID-19 in people who were reportedly infected with the virus type BA.4 that was apparently derived from the omicron, which indicates that it is more contagious than the omicron, although there was not enough time to assess whether this would mean a rapid outbreak of the disease.</s>

en: Although the BA.4 version of COVID-19's omicron variant appears more infectious than omicron, WHO said there was no evidence yet that it was leading to substantially higher rates of hospitalization or death.
sna: Kunyangwe hazvo BA.4 iyo yakabukira kubva omicron inovawo davi reCOVID-19 richiratidza kuva nehasha yekupararira nekukasira kudarika omicron, WHO yakati pakange pasina humboo hwairatidza kuti yakange ichibva yakonzera kuwedzera kwevarwere vaiendeswa kuzvipatara kana kuwanda kwendufu. there was no evidence yet that it was leading to substantially higher rates of hospitalization or death.
mt0: <pad> Although BA.4, a variant of omicron, a COVID-19 vaccine, showed a faster spread than omicron, the WHO said there was no yet evidence that it was leading to substantially higher rates of hospitalization or death.</s>

en: Salim Abdool Karim, a public health expert at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, said that while only a "modest" rise in cases had been noted, South Africa was also in the middle of a holiday period and testing had dropped significantly.
sna: Salim Abdool Karim, nyanzvi inoona nezvehutano hweveruzhinji ichishandira paUniversity of KwaZulu-Natal, akati kunyangwe paive nekuwedzera "kwakadzikama" muhuwandu hwevanhu vakabatwa nedenda kwakaonekwa, South Africa yakange iri pakati penguva yezororo uyewo kuongororwa kuti vanhu vane chirwere here kwakange kwaderera zvikuru.
mt0: <pad> Salim Abdool Karim, a public health expert at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, said while there was a "steady" increase in the number of people affected by the virus, South Africa was in the middle of the holiday season and tests for the disease were very low.</s>

en: He said the cases were slowing and were "not following a rocket-like upward trajectory we would expect" in another spike of disease.
sna: Akati huwnadu hwevanhu vane denda hwakange huchiratidza kudzikira uye "hwusingatevedzeri kutushikira kuenda mudenga sechitendemuseresere zvatinotarisira" panowedzera kupararira kweimwewo mhando yechirwere.
mt0: <pad> He said the number of people with the disease was showing signs of decline and "not following the upward spiral we expect" when the spread of another type of disease increased.</s>

en: At a press briefing on Wednesday, WHO emergencies chief Dr. Michael Ryan said it was too soon to tell if COVID-19 was entering a seasonal pattern and warned against countries dropping all of their restrictions too quickly as many in the West have done.
sna: Pachiitiko chekutura mashoko kuvatapi venhau neChitatu, mukuru anoona nezvetsaona nenjodzi Dr. Michael Ryan akati zvinenge zvakurumidzirwa kuti vanhu vagone kunyatsoona kuti COVID-19 yange yatora mutoo wekuwanda mukati memwaka yegore, uyewo vakayambira nyika dzavakurerutsa matanho ekudzivirira denda iri nekukasira sezvakaitwa nenyika zhinji dzekumavirira.
mt0: <pad> At a press conference on Wednesday, the director of risk and emergency Dr. Michael Ryan said it was too early to see if COVID-19 had reached its peak in this year, and he warned countries that they were not taking measures to prevent the disease as quickly as many eastern countries have done.</s>

en: The jury is still out as to how seasonal this virus will become, he said, explaining that it wasn't proven yet that COVID-19 would naturally drop off in the summer and that the world could yet face more unsettling variants.
sna: Hazvisati zvava pachena kuti denda iri richange richitevedza mwaka yegore here, vakadaro, vachitsnangura kuti zvakange zvisati zvaratidzwa nehumboo hunoibatika kuti COVID-19 yazoderera yega munguva yezhizha vakati nyika dzepasi rose dzaigona kusangana nedzimwe mhando dzedenda iri dzinovhundutsa.
mt0: <pad> It is not yet clear whether the pandemic will change over the coming year, they said, explaining that there was no reliable evidence that COVID-19 would decline itself in the summer and that the world could face other unexpected variants of the disease.</s>

en: "If people are crowded together in conditions where a new variant is spreading, you will see high levels of transmission," he said.
sna: "Kana vanhu vakaminyana mumamiriro ezvinhu ekuti mhando itsva yedenda iri kupararira, uchazoona kuwanda kuzhinji kwekutarirana nekupararira kwechirwere," akadaro.
mt0: <pad> "When people are exposed to a new type of disease, you will see a greater increase in transmission and the spread of the disease," he said.</s>

en: Meanwhile in China, authorities continued to crack down on cities, including Beijing, where more than 10% of the subway system was shut down in an effort to curb the virus' spread, after authorities in the capital already closed down indoor dining, gyms and school classes.
sna: Zvichadaro kuChina, vakuru vakaenderera mberi kumhanikidzira matanho ekuderedza kupararira kwedenda zvine chisimba mumaguta, kusanganisira Beijing, umo zvikamu gumi kubva muzana zvenjanji dzezvitima zvinofamba nepasi pezvivakwa nemigwagwa zvakavharwa mukuedza kuderedza kupararira kwedenda iri, mushure mekunge vakuru muguta guru vakange vatofanovharisa kudyiwa kwechikafu mudzimba dzinotengesa zvokudya, nzvimbo dzinotatatmurwa miviri nekudzidziswa kwevana vari muzvikoro.
mt0: <pad> In China, authorities have continued to push for tougher measures to curb the spread of the disease in cities, including Beijing, where ten percent of under-ground transit lines and buildings and roads have been closed in an attempt to curb the spread of the disease, after the capital city authorities had already closed food shops, gyms and school education.</s>

en: In Shanghai, rigid and widely derided restrictions have led to shortages of food and medical aid along with a wider though likely temporary impact on the national economy.
sna: MuShanghai, matanho akaomarara asi achishoorwa nevanhu vazhinji ari kunzera kushaikwa kwezvekudya nerubetsero rwezvemishonga pamwe chete nekukanganisika kwezvehupfumi hwenyika kunyange hazvo izvi zvisingazogare kwenguva refu.
mt0: <pad> In Shanghai, harsh but widely accepted measures are causing shortages of food and medical aid as well as a national economic depression even though this cannot last for long.</s>

en: Desperate, outraged citizens have confronted authorities at barricades and online, screamed out of their windows and banged pots and pans in a sign of frustration and anger.
sna: Vagari vemuguta vashayaiwa zano asi vakatsamwa chose, vakamisidzana nemapurisa akange akaisa zvinhu mumigwagwa zvinodzivisa vanhu kufamba, uyewo nepamadandemutande vachisheedzera kubva mumafafitera edzimba dzavo, nekurova mapoto senzira yekugumbuka nekushaya zvekuita.
mt0: <pad> The residents of the city were left in shock but very upset, clashing with policemen who had put barricades on the streets, and on the internet shouting from their windows, banging on the doors as a sign of anger and frustration.</s>

en: Myanmar Supreme Court Rejects Aung San Suu Kyi Appeal on Corruption Charges
sna: Dare  Repamusoro remuMyanmar Rinokandira Kunze Chikumbiro Cha Aung San Suu Kyi Kuti Nyaya Dzaarikupomerwa Dzehuori Dzitarisiswezve
mt0: <pad> The Myanmar Supreme Court Rejects Aung San Suu Kyi's Request for Her Sexual Abuse Cases to be Investigated</s>

en: An appeal of a five-year jail sentence against ousted Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi was rejected Wednesday by the country's supreme court.
sna: Chikumbiro chemutungamiriri we Myanmar uyo akabviswa pachigaro, Aung San Suu Kyi chekuongororwazve kwekutongerwa kugara mujeri kwemakore mashanu chakarambwa neChitatu nedare repamuso remunyika iyi.
mt0: <pad> The request of Myanmar's dissident leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, for her five-year jail term was refused by the country's highest court on Wednesday.</s>

en: The decision reportedly came as soon as the claim for an appeal was lodged, and the court didn't entertain arguments from either side in the case.
sna: Kutonga kwedare uku kunonzi kwakaturwa mapepa ekuti nyaya iyi iongororwe achangounzwa, uye dare iri rakaramba kunzwa zvachose zvaitaurwa nevachuchusi vehurumende nemagweta aSuu Kyi.
mt0: <pad> The court's decision comes after the papers for the trial were filed, and the court refused to hear any statements made by the government or the lawyers of Aung San Suu Kyi.</s>

en: Suu Kyi, 76, was sentenced last week after being found guilty of 11 counts of corruption, including taking a bribe of cash and gold bars worth $600,000.
sna: Amai Suu Kyi, vane makore makumi manomwe nematanhatu vakatongwa svondo rakapera mushure mekuwanikwa vaine mhosva gumi neimwe dzehuori, kusanganisira kutambira mari yefufuro nemagodo egorodhe ane hukoshi hunodarika zviuru mazana matanhatu emadhora.
mt0: <pad> Aung San Suu Kyi, 84, was convicted last week after being found guilty of 11 felony counts, including accepting bribes and gold jewellery worth over $160 million.</s>

en: Her lawyer called the charge absurd.
sna: Gweta  ravo rakati kupomerwa uku hakuna musoro.
mt0: <pad> Their lawyer said the charges were unfounded.</s>

en: Suu Kyi had already been sentenced to six years for actions against the military, breaking COVID-19 rules and breaking a telecommunications law.
sna: Amai Suu Kyi vakange vatotongerwa kugara mujeri kwemakore matanhatu nekuda kwezvakaita zvekudzivisa mauto, kutyora mitemo yekudzivirira kupararira kwedenda reCOVID-19 uye nekutyora mitemo yezvekushandisa mishina yekutaura nevamwe yakaita sedzinhare, nharembozha nemapotonjere.
mt0: <pad> The Myanmar opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi was sentenced to six years in jail for her anti-government activities, violation of the Covid-19 restrictions and violation of the communications laws such as telephone, mobile phone and fax.</s>

en: She faces many more charges, and if found guilty could be sentenced to more than 150 years in jail.
sna: Vachiri vakatarisana nedzimwe mhosva dzavari kupomerwa, uye kana vakawanikwa vaine mhosva vanogona kutongerwa kugara mujeri kwemakore anodarika zana nemakumi mashanu.
mt0: <pad> They are still facing other charges, and if convicted they can face up to 150 years in prison.</s>

en: Suu Kyi has been under house arrest since a military coup took over the country last year.

en: Saudi Arabia is pushing to revamp its harsh justice system but reforms are overshadowed by executions and tough treatment of dissidents, raising questions about how much will change.
sna: Saudi Arabia iri kushanda kuti inatsiridze mashandisirwe ezvemutemo wayo uyo une hukasha, asi shanduko dziri kukanganiswa nekugurwa misoro nekubatwa zvine chisimba kwevapanduki, zvasiya pava nemibvunzo yekuti zvinhu zvingani zvichanyatsoshanduka.
mt0: <pad> Saudi Arabia is working to strengthen its strict sharia law, but reforms are being hampered by the executions and brutal detainment of dissidents, leaving questions about how much real change will be made.</s>

en: The kingdom is known for its strict interpretation of Islamic sharia law, which forms the basis of its judicial system.

mt0: <pad> The country is known for its strict application of the Islamic law, the sharia, which is the basis of the country's legal system.</s>

en: But in recent months it has moved ahead with reforms that analysts say could make its courts function more like others in the Middle East.
sna: Asi mumwezi ichangodarika, yakaenderera mberi nekushanduro idzo vanonzvera nekuongorora vanoti zvinogona kuita kuti matare edzimhosva ayo ashande sezvinoita mamwe mudunhu reMiddle East.
mt0: <pad> But last month it continued with reforms that analysts say could make its judiciary work like other Middle East courts.</s>

mt0: <pad> The whole work is focused on a set of new laws that address difficult issues to talk about such as the rights of women after divorce and the power of judges to impose punishments in criminal cases.</s>

en: Announced last year by de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the measures, including the first written penal code, appear to align with Saudi Arabia's goal of opening up to the world and softening its extremist image.
sna: Matanho aya, akaziviswa gore rakapera munhu ari pachinzvimbo chemutungamiriri chaiye, Nevanji Mohammed bin Salman, anosanganisira zvinyorwa zvekutanga zvine nzira dzekuranga, anoita sekubatana nechinangwa cheSaudi Arabia chekumbundikira zviri kuitwa nedzimwe nyika uyewo nekunyevenutsa maonerwo ayinoitwa senyika inokakatira kurutivi.
mt0: <pad> The measures, announced last year by the vice-royalty, Prince Mohammed bin Salman, include the first military weapons, seem to be in line with Saudi Arabia's goal of suppressing other countries' actions and to soften its image as a country that remains isolated.</s>

en: Even critics concede the changes could make Saudi courts more predictable, in some cases.

mt0: <pad> Although some critics agree that the changes may lead to some Saudi courts being questioned in their handling of criminal cases, they do not know how they will be used in the future.</s>

en: But there is no expectation that restrictions on free speech will ease, or that the legal system will treat more favorably perceived opponents of the government.

mt0: <pad> But no one expects that the restrictions on people's freedom of expression will be reduced, or that you will treat people who are seen as government enemies better.</s>

en: And despite the reforms, authorities have simultaneously provided reminders of what gave Saudi Arabia its ruthless reputation in the first place, notably the mass execution of 81 men in a single day in March for offenses related to "terrorism."

mt0: <pad> And while there are these changes, the international community is also giving a reminder of Saudi Arabia's long history of cruelty, particularly the mass murder of eighty men on the same day in March with charges of "terrorism."</s>

en: Under sharia, only apostasy, theft, revolt, armed robbery, adultery, drinking alcohol and slander carry prescribed sentences. Judges are left to determine punishment in other cases.

mt0: <pad> Under the sharia law, apostasy, stealing, rebellion, robbery, prostitution, drinking and libel are all punishable by predetermined penalties. Judges are left to decide on other charges.</s>

en: With a penal code in place, "the state will expect judges to rely not on their own training in sharia but instead on the legal rules (based on sharia) approved by the state," said Nathan Brown, an academic at George Washington University.
sna: Gwaro rezvirango ravapo kudai, "hurumende ichatarisira vatongi kuzembera kwete pane zvavakadzidziswa kumutemo we sharia asi pane gwara remutemo (asi wakamira pahwaro hwe sharia) rakatenderwa nehurumende," akadaro Nathan Brown, nyanzvi yezveruzivo yepa George Washington University.

en: As a result, Saudi Arabia will look much more like a civil law system, much like most states in the region, said Brown, who has studied the Saudi reforms.

mt0: <pad> So, Saudi Arabia will become a cosmopolitan state, like many other countries in the region, said Brown, who was monitoring the reforms in Saudi Arabia.</s>

en: The result should be more "predictability," said Abdullah Alaoudh, a U.S.-based legal expert and government critic, as new rules "take away from the leeway ... that the judges used to have."

mt0: <pad> The result is that there is a "constant knowledge of the process and methods used," said Abdullah Alaoudh, a legal expert who lives in the U.S. and a government spokesman, as new laws "remove from the market and taxes.... which the authorities did not know before."</s>

mt0: <pad> As Americans Go Less To Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill That Gap?</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society.
sna: Makereke nedzimwe nzvimbo dzekunamatira dzakagara dziine basa guru munezvekugarisana kwevanhu nezvematongorwo muhugaro hwekuAmerica. Asi vanhu vashomanana vava kuenda kushumiro, uye kuderera uku mudzikereke nedzimwe nzvimbo dzekunamatira dzavakusiya mukaha waiogona kungozadziswa koga nezvitoro zvinotengesa svutugadzike yerudzi rwekofi.
mt0: <pad> Churches and other religious institutions have always had a large role in American social and cultural history. But people are fewer going to church, and the decline in churches and other religious institutions has been driven by stores that sell a cup of coffee.</s>

en: But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
sna: Asi vanhu vashomanana vava kuenda kushumiro, uye kuderera uku mudzikereke nedzimwe nzvimbo dzekunamatira dzavakusiya mukaha waiogona kungozadziswa koga nezvitoro zvinotengesa svutugadzike yerudzi rwekofi.
mt0: <pad> But fewer people are going to church, and the decline in churches and other places of worship that have been abandoned in the past may be caused by a growing number of stores that sell a cup of coffee.</s>

en: For so much of American history, the church has really been or their congregations have really been essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities encouraging civic engagement and political participation, says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
sna: Munhorondo zhinji yeAmerica, kereke kana kuti zvaunga zvemakereke, zvakange zvakakosha zviita basa risina vamwe vakamboriita rekuunza kubatana nemidzi yehukama munzvimbo dzigere vanhu, kukurudzira kuti vagari vemunzvimbo vapinzwa muhurongwa hwunobata hupenyu hwavo uye nekuridzira vagri kuti kuti vave nechekuita mune zvematongerwo, anodaro Daniel Cox, mukuru we Survey Center on American Life nemunzveri mukuru weAmerican Enterprise Institute.
mt0: <pad> In many American cases, churches or church-based institutions have been important in bringing together and building relationships in neighborhoods, encouraging community participation in the affairs of the community and encouraging community political participation, says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.</s>

en: It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church, Cox says.
sna: Zvakange zvisiri zvemasanga kana zverombo rakanaka kuti boka rairwira kodzero dzevagari vemuAmerica rakasimuka richibva mukereke, anodaroCox.
mt0: <pad> It was not a good or bad luck that the American Civil Rights movement started from the church, says Cox.</s>

en: And you see that cross-culturally whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important.
sna: Uye unozoona kuti zvakatariswa mutsika nemagariro evanhu vakasiyana siyana, zvisineyi kuti hugaro hwevachena chete vari kumaruma here, mumisha yevapfumi mumadhorobha, kupi nekupi zvako, makereke munhorondo yevanhu, agara achikosha zvikurusa.
mt0: <pad> And you see that they have been taken into account in different cultures and traditions, whether it is white culture in the colonies, in rich towns or anywhere else, churches in human history have always been of great importance.</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
sna: Cox anoti, 'Makereke nedzimwe nzvimbo dzekunamatira akaita basa kubatsira vanhu vanenge vatama vachibva kune dzimwe nyika kuti vakwane mutsika nemagariro matsva avanenge vapinda maari pavanosvika muAmerica."
mt0: <pad> Cox says, "Churches and other places of worship have done a great job of helping immigrants adapt to the new culture and society they have come into contact with when they arrive in America."</s>

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
sna: Muna 1999, vanhu zvikamu makumi manomwe kubva muzana vemuAmerica vakati inhengo yekerek, mosque kana synagogue.
mt0: <pad> In 1999, seventy percent of Americans said they were members of a church, mosque or synagogue.</s>

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
sna: Pakazosvika 2020, huwandu uhwu hwakange hwaderera kusvika pavanhu zvikamu makumi mana nevanomwe kubva muzana. Imwe tsvakurudzo muna 2019 yakaona kuti vanhu vemuAmerica vatatu kubva mugumi ndivo voga vayienda kushumiro yechinamato yesvondo nesvondo.
mt0: <pad> In 2020, this number had fallen to 47 percent. A study in 2019 found that only three percent of Americans attended a Sunday service.</s>

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
sna: Nzvimbo Dzechitatu Kusabatana kana kuva nenhengo yemakereke, ma mosques nema synagogue zvinoreva kuti vanhu vanenge vachirasikirwa neizvo zvinonzi nenyanzvi inoongorora magariro netsika dzemumadhorobha,Ray Oldenburg, akadaidza kuti "nzvimbo dzechitatu" nzvimbo dziendwa neveruzhinji dzinopa munhu chimwe chinhu chekuti chaasingapihwe kumba inova "nzvimbo yekutanga" nekubasa inova "nzvimbo yechipiri".
mt0: <pad> The Third Place Not being involved in churches, mosques or synagogue means that people are losing what Ray Oldenburg, a social and cultural expert, called "third places" public spaces that offer something that cannot be offered at home, the "first place," or at work, the "second place."</s>

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
sna: Oldenburg anoti nzvimbo dzechitatu idzi dzakakosha pakuunza hutano kumagariro anoita vanhu munzvimbo yavanenge vagere.
mt0: <pad> Oldenburg says that the thirds are important in bringing health to people's sleep habits.</s>

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
sna: Tsvakurudzo yakaitwa muna 2021 nesangano rezvetsvakurudzo muAmerica re American Survey Center rakaona kuti  nzvimbo dzinoitwa zvekutengesera vanhu dzakaita sezvitoro zvinotengesa svutugadzike dzinovaka kuvimbikana nekubatana munzvimbo dzinogara vanhu vemuAmerica, uye dzaigona kuzadza mukaha wakasiiwa nemakereke.
mt0: <pad> Research conducted in 2021 by the American Survey Center found that retail stores like grocery stores build trust and connections in American neighborhoods, and could fill the gap left by churches.</s>

en: If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good, says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
sna: Kana uri munhu anosienda panzvimbo inotengeswa svutugadzike, mubuki wesvutugadzike anogona kunge ava kutoziva kuti unotenga rudzi ipi yacho, uye izvi zvinoita kuti munhu anzwe zvakanaka, anodaro anoona chiremba nezvehutano hwemanzwiro nekufunga kwevanhu, Dr. Maria Espinola, uyo ari muzvinafundo mubazi rinodzidzisa zvehutano hwepfungwa nehunhu nemaitiro evanhu reDepartment of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience paUniversity of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
mt0: <pad> If you're a frequent visitor to a convenience store, the clerk may even know what kind of cigarette you're buying, and that makes you feel good, says Dr. Maria Espinola, professor of psychiatry and behavioral neuroscience at the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.</s>

en: It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways, Espinola says.
sna: Espinola anoti, "Zvinoita kuti munhu anzwe zvakanaka maari kana vanhu vakamuziva kuti ndiani, kuziva kuti vanhu vakakutarisira kuti usvike,  kuziva kuti vanhu vane hanya newe, kuziva kuti unkowo kwaunoti ndekwangu, nekuti chishuvo chekuva nekunonzi nemunhu ndiko kwake kune nekwake vaanoyanana nekudyidzana navo chinhu chakakosha chinodiwa nesu tese zvaedu, uye zvakakosha kuti chazadzikiswa nenzira dzakasiya."
mt0: <pad> Espinola says, "It makes a person feel good about himself when people know who he is, knowing that people expect you to come, knowing that people care about you, knowing that you have a place you can call your own, because the wish to have a sense of belonging to others is a fundamental need for all of us, and it is important that it is fulfilled by the ways that have been abandoned."</s>

en: So, places like third places can allow us to do that.
sna: Saka nzvimbo dzakaita dzechitatu dzinotipa mukana wekuita izvi.
mt0: <pad> So third-party sites give us the opportunity to do this.</s>

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
sna: Munguva dzakadarika, makereke nedzimwe nzvimbo dzekunamatira, dzakange dziri idzo nzvombo dzechitatu kevanhu vazhinji vekuAmerica.
mt0: <pad> In the past, churches and other places of worship were the third most important place for many Americans.</s>

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
sna: Muna 2019, zvikamu zvevanhu makuma matanhatu nevanomwe kubva muzana yevanhu vakataurwa navo mutsvakurudzo vakati vane nzvimbo yechitatu ” iri chitoro chinotengeswa svutugadzike bhawa, nzvimbo inotengeswa chikafu chakabikwa, nzvimbo yeekutandararira ine maruva miti nesora rakachekererwa kana imwewo nzvimbo iri munzvimbo dzavagere dzavanogona kushanyira nguva nenguva..
mt0: <pad> In 2019, seventy-eight percent of the people interviewed said they had a "third place" which is a coffee shop, bakery, park with flowers and a covered porch or other location in their neighborhood that they could frequent regularly.</s>

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
sna: Hwuwandu uhwu hwakadonha kusvika pavanhu zvikamu makumi mashanu nevatanhu kubva muzana izvo zvaigona kunge zvakonzereswa nedenda redzihwamupengo reCOVID-19.
mt0: <pad> This number fell to twenty-five percent, possibly attributed to the coronavirus disease COVID-19.</s>

en: What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community, says Cox.
sna: Cox anoti, ' Zvatakaona ndezvekuti vanhu vane nzvimbo yechitatu vakange vaine hukama nekudyidyana munzvimbo dzavanogara. Vane mukana mukuru wekuti vane zvimwewo zvinhu zvavanogona kuita nevamwe munzvimbo idzodzo."
mt0: <pad> Cox says, "What we found was that people with third place had a stronger connection to and interaction with their community. They have a greater chance of having other things to do with others in those communities."</s>

en: "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
sna: Vane mukana mukuru wekuti vane zvimwewo zvinhu zvavanogona kuita nevamwe munzvimbo idzodzo."
mt0: <pad> They have a great chance that they can do other things with others in those places.</s>

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors.
sna: Vanonyanya kuvimba nevavakidzani vavo.
mt0: <pad> They depend heavily on their neighbors.</s>

en: There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
sna: Pane zvakanaka zvakawanda zvekugarisana nevamwe kunobuda zvakabuda mukuva nenzvimbo yechitatu, uye kuvanhu vazhinji vekuAmerica, inzvimbo inotengeswa svutigadzike yekofi kana yetii"
mt0: <pad> There are many good things about social relationships that come from being in the third place, and for many Americans, it's a place that sells a cup of coffee or tea.</s>

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
sna: Chakanakira nzvimbo dzesvutugadzike idzi ndechekuti dzinowakwa kwese kwese munyika yese, uye wese anenge achiida anogona kupfuura nepo paanenge adira nguva nengua.
mt0: <pad> The advantage of these sites is that they are built all over the country, and any interested person can visit them at his own pace and time.</s>

en: And many are open most days of the week.
sna: Nzvimbo zhinji idzi dzinenge dzakavhura mazuva mazhinji esvondo rese.
mt0: <pad> Many of these places are open most days of the week.</s>

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
sna: Cox anoti kunyangwe kusangana kwechinguva chidoko nevamwe muuzvitoro zvesvutugadzike izvi kunowedzera pakuti munhu anzwe kuti ndine vekwangu nenzvimbo yandinogamuchirika.
mt0: <pad> Cox says that even a short time with others in these stores adds to the sense of having a family and a place to be accepted.</s>

en: I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential, Cox says.
sna: Cox anoti, '' Ndinofunga kuti pane mukana wekuita zvakawanda, mukana wekuita zvakawanda usiri kuonekwa nekushandiswa."
mt0: <pad> Cox said, "I think there is a lot of potential for more, a lot of potential that is not being seen and used.</s>

en: But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
sna: Asi panyaya yekuti chii chinogona kuitwa, pane zvakawanda zvinogona kuitwa ipapo.
mt0: <pad> But when it comes to what can be done, there are a lot of things that can be done there.</s>

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
sna: Ndinosipinda munzvimbo dzekuti chikwata chimwe chetecho chevanhu chinouya kuzotamba tsoro dze chess.
mt0: <pad> I used to go to places where a group of people come to play chess games.</s>

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees.
sna: Kana kuti vane boka vega revanhu vakasiya mabasa nekukura.
mt0: <pad> Or they have another group of people who have left their jobs as they grow up.</s>

en: They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other.
sna: Vakangosangana ndokutanga kuraura nekukurukura, vanike votowirirana.
mt0: <pad> They just met and began to talk and talk, and they seemed to agree.</s>

en: I don't know where else they would have gone maybe a church, but maybe not to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
sna: Handizive imwe nzvimbo yavaigona kuenda, zvichida kukereke, asi vasingagoverane ruzivo nezviri kuitika, kukurudzirana, pamwe kuri kuti vane zvanoita vari pamwe chete.
mt0: <pad> I don't know where they could go, maybe church, but without sharing information, encouraging each other, or even doing something together.</s>

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops.
sna: Uye ndinofunga kuti izvi ndizvo zvinoita kuti nzvimbo dzesvutugadzike idzi dzive nemutsindo wakadai.
mt0: <pad> And I think that's what makes these sites so powerful.</s>

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
sna: Chiri  kushungurudza vakuru vemaguta ekuAmerica mushure medenda
mt0: <pad> The American oil industry is being hit by the fall in oil prices after the oil crisis.</s>

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
sna: Vakuru vemaguta emuAmerica varikunetsekana zvikuru nemusarirwa hwezvinetswa zvehutano hwepfungwa mushure medenda redzihwamupengo reCOVID-19, ndizvo zvakabuda mutsvakurudzo yenyika yose yakaitwa nevakuru vemaguta zana nemakumi maviri nematanhatu muzhizha ra2021.
mt0: <pad> The United States states are mostly concerned about the impact of mental health problems after COVID-19, according to a national survey conducted by 120 state representatives in 2021.</s>

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents.
sna: Vakapinda mutsvakurudzo idzi vaitungamirira maguta ane vanhu vasiri pasi pezviuru makumi masere nevashanu.
mt0: <pad> The cities that participated in the research were those with populations below 885,000.</s>

en: The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
sna: Vakuru venzvimbo ava vachiri vakanangisa panyaya dzaisida kugadziriswa dzakaita sekuparwa kwemhosva nechisimba zvinosiya dzakuvadza vanhu, zvehupfumi nezvivakwa zvinoshandiswa neveruzhinji, asiwo vachiri kushushikana zvikuru nezvakasiiwa zvaitwa nedenda iri zvicharamba zvichinetsa vanhu kwenguva refu ichateverazvikuru seyi pane zvehutano hwepfungwa dzevanhu vanogara mumaguta avanotungamirira.
mt0: <pad> The local authorities are still focused on the problems that need to be addressed such as crime, economic and public facilities, but are also concerned about the legacy of the disease that will continue to affect the people for a long time, especially on mental health of the people who live in the cities they are responsible for.</s>

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
sna: Hutano hwepfungwa ndicho chinhu chaive pamusoro pezvinhu zvese mupfungwa dzaMichael Udine apo akagadzwa kuva mutungamiriri weBroward County, iri muFlorida, muna Mbudzi wa2021.
mt0: <pad> Mental health was the thing that was on top of everything for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in December 2021.</s>

en: Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic, he says.
sna: Zvese zvaigoina kuva zvinhu zvainetsa ndednda risati rauya, zvakabva zvatowedzerwa nekuuya kwakaita denda, anodaro.
mt0: <pad> All these problems were already there before the pandemic, but they got worse with the pandemic, he said.</s>

en: "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages.
sna: "Tisati tapinda mudenda paive nezvinhu zvakawanda, uye zvakange zvavakukosha mumeso emunhu wese panyaya yehutano hwepfungwa dzevanhu vemazera ose zvawo.
mt0: <pad> "Before the revolution there were many things, and very important in everyone's eyes, about mental health of people of all ages.</s>

en: And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
sna: Uye ndinofunga kuti denda rakabva rawedzera moto panyaya idzodzi dzoseu."
mt0: <pad> And I think the crisis has intensified all these issues.</s>

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
sna: Sangano rinoona nezvekudzivirirwa kwezvirwere nekupararira kwazvo re Center for Disease Control and Prevention rinoti hachisi chinhu chiinoshamisa kuti kuputika kukuru kwematenda kuve nezvinetswa zvakunosiya muhutano hwepfungwa dzevanhu. Sangano iri rinotiwo kuwedzera kwekushushikana nezvirwere zvinokonzerswa nekusagadzikana kwepfungwa pakati pevanhu vakuru kwakawedzera munguva yedenda iri.
mt0: <pad> The Center for Disease Control and Prevention says it is not surprising that pandemics have a negative impact on mental health. It also says the increase in depression and other mental illnesses among elderly people has been higher during the pandemic.</s>

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
sna: Dwenda iri rakakanganisawo hutano hwepfungwa nemanzwiro endangariro echikamu chimwe chete kubva muzvitatu zvevechidiki vekuAmerica.
mt0: <pad> The disease also affected the mental and emotional health of one-third of American young people.</s>

en: What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions, Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month.
sna: Chiremba anoona nezvepfungwa mudunhu reMaryland, Mary Karapetian Alvord, akaudza VOA mwedzi wakapera kuti, "Zvatichangobva mukuona kunongova kushushikana kwepfungwa uku kwekuti hakwaigona kubva kwashungurudza pfungwa dzevechidiki meltdown, nekuti pakave neshandu zhinji uye kuomerwa nekujairirana nekuyambukira munzira itsva dzekurarama nadzo.
mt0: <pad> The psychiatrist in Maryland, Mary Karapetian Alvord, told the VOA last month that "What we have seen is this mild depression that cannot be a real youth meltdown, because there were many divorces and difficulty adapting to and transitioning into new life styles."</s>

en: "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
sna: Takaonawo kusurikirwa nekutsimbirirwa muzvinzwo zvepfungwa kwakanyaya"
mt0: <pad> We also saw the loss and abuse of mental health.</s>

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
sna: David Glick, muzvinafundo wezvematongerwo paBoston University uye ari mumwe wevaviri vakanyora tsakurudzo pausoro pevakuru vemaguta iyi inonzi 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors, akati, "Denda iri richangotanga, vakuru vemaguta vakange vakanangisana nekufambiswa kwebasa remazuva ose remumaguta avo, kusakwana kwemari yakatemerwa mabasa akasiyana siyana,uye nenjodzi yaigona kuunzwa nedenda kunemabhizimisi madiki.
mt0: <pad> David Glick, a professor of politics at Boston University and one of the two authors of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors, said, "When the pandemic began, mayors were concerned with the daily running of their cities, the shortage of funding for different services, and the potential risk posed by the pandemic to small business."</s>

en: Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents, Glick says.
sna: Zvimwe zvezvinetso izvi zvichiripo, asi chatakanyanya kuona muna 2021 zvaive zvinoshungurudza zvinozoitika mumakore anouya zvicharamba zvichishungurudza vagari, Glick anodaro.
mt0: <pad> Some of these problems are still there, but what we saw in 2021 was the most troubling and the future will continue to be troubling for people, Glick said.</s>

en: "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
sna: "Zvinetswa pamusoro pekuiswa kwevanhu mumapoka anokwikwidzana pamaonero panyaya yemishonga yekudzivirira denda uye nekungoti vanhu vari kusundwa kusvikira kumawere pakuti chii chavanogona kutakura muprungwa dzavo, uye hapasisina kunetsekana nezvekushandiswa kwemari muguta, kupunda kwemari kana kumisa humwe hurongwa uyewo zvimwe zvinhu zvakaita saizvozvi izvo zvaigona kunge zvaive zviri zvinhu zvaikosheswa mupfungwa pakatanga denda iri."
mt0: <pad> "We are concerned about the division of people into competing groups in regard to the drug vaccine and that people are being dragged to the brink by what they can bring in their ships, and there is no concern about the city's financial management, the lack of money or the disruption of other programs and such things that might have been the most important considerations when this pandemic began."</s>

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey.
sna: Chikamu chinodarika chepakati nepakati chevatungamiriri vemaguta ava chinosvika makumi mashanu nezviviri kubva muzana zvichiri kunetsekana "nemusairirwa wemadambudziko muhutano hwepfungwa nezvinotyisa zvinoramba zvirimupfungwa nendangariro," zvinodaro zvakanyorwa mune zvakabuda mutsvakurudzo.
mt0: <pad> Over half of these city leaders still suffer from "persistent mental health problems and traumatic experiences in the mind and memory," according to research results.</s>

en: Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
sna: Pamusoro pazvo chikamu chimwe chete kubva muzvitatu chevatungamiriri vemaguta aya, kana kuti zvikamu makumi matatu nevanomwe kubva muzana vainetsekana nekurasikirwa nenguva yekudzidza  kune vvediki..
mt0: <pad> Over the course of these three years, one-third of these city leaders, or thirty-eight percent were concerned about the loss of time for education to the media.</s>

en: Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns, Glick says.
sna: Izvi zvinotevera hutano hwepfungwa nezvinotyisa zvinosarira mupfungwa nendandangariro mushure mekunge munhu asangana netsaona inotyisa, uye hazvinganzi izvi zvinhu zvakatsaurwa kubva pane zvimwe zvinhu zvinoda kutariswa, anodaro Glick.
mt0: <pad> This follows mental health and psychological trauma and depression after a traumatic event, and it cannot be said that these things have been separated from other issues to be considered, says Glick.</s>

en: "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future.
sna: "Chikamu chezvinofanirwa kuitwa zvichitangira panjodzi yekuti mabhizimisi anogona kunyura zvachose uye nekuti vanhu vanogona kurwara zvichizobatawo zvimwe zvinetswa zvinobva pamatambudziko ariko aya, asi zvichizooonekwa kwapera makore akati kuti.
mt0: <pad> "Part of the action is based on the risk that companies may completely sink and people may get ill, which will bring about other problems from these same problems, but they will be seen after a few years."</s>

en: And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
sna: Uye kusakirwa nenguva yekudzidza pakati pevadzidzi, vanotya kuti izvi zvicharamba zvichitika kwemakore nemakore akawanda mune ramangwana. Zvakaoma chose kuti izvi zvigadziriswe."
mt0: <pad> And the shortage of study time among students, they fear that this will continue for many years in the future. It's very difficult to fix.</s>

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
sna: Maringe netsvakurudzo iyi, zvimwe zvinhu zviri pamusoro pazvinhu zvishungurudza vatungamiriri vemaguta ekuAmerica, zvinosanganisira kusachengetedzeka pane zvemari pakati pevagari vanotambira mari shomanana, avo vane huwandu hunesvika pazvikamu makumi matatu nezvitatu kubva muzana, kunyura kwemabhizimisi madoko  izvo zvakaonekwa kuti zvinotora chinzvimbo che zvikamu makumi maviri nezvipfumbamwe kubva muzana uyewo nekuwedzera kuparwa mhosva nehugeven'a  izvo zvakatora zvikamu makumi maviri nezvitanhatu kubva muzana.
mt0: <pad> According to this study, other issues that have affected American state leaders include insecure financial status among low-income citizens, who account for 33 percent, the downturn of small business which accounted for 19 percent and the increase in crime and criminality which accounted for 26 percent.</s>

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration people moving away from their cities.
sna: Zvikamu zvinomwe kubva muzana zvoga zvavatungamiriri vemaguta ava ndivo vanoshushikana nenyaya dzekuti vanhu vanenge voita mabasa avo vari kure nenzvimbo dzekushandira vachishandisa mapotonjere nemadandemutande uye zvakaipa zvinozobuda pazviri mushure memakore akati kuti apo vagare vachange votama vachienda kunogara mune mamwe maguta.
mt0: <pad> Seven percent of these city leaders are worried about the remote working of people using computers and the internet and the problems that will emerge after a few years when they move to other cities.</s>

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns.
sna: Mari yekushandisa inosvika mabhiriyoni mazana matatu nemakumi mashanu yakabva kuhurongwa hwekuyambutsa maguta nehurunmende dzemumatunhu ari parumananzombe inonzi American Rescue Plan yaigona kubatsira vatungamiriri vemaguta kuti vavagadzirise zvimwe zvezvinetswa zvavo.
mt0: <pad> The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan could help state leaders address some of their problems.</s>

en: The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
sna: Tsvakurudzo iyi yakaonawo zvakare kuti zvikamu makumi manimwe nezvisere zvevatungamiriri vemaguta zvine ruvimbo rwekuti mari iyi ichavatendera kuti vaunze shanduko inobatsira.
mt0: <pad> The study also found that eighteen percent of local officials believed the money would allow them to make positive change.</s>

en: What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities, Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
sna: Glick anoti, "Zvatiri kuona ndezvekuti vatungamiriri vakawanda vemaguta vari kushandisa mari iyi pane zvunhu zvavanofunga kuti zvinesimba rekuburitsa shanduko uye kuti zvichaunza shanduko huru mumaguta avo vasinganzwe kugombedzerwa kana kunzwa kufanira kuvhara maburi nemakomba pamari isiri kukwana kuita basa remuguta kuti guta rirambe richishanda semazuva ose uye riine magetsi."
mt0: <pad> Glick said, "What we see is that most city leaders are using the money on projects that they think will spark change and make a big difference in their cities without feeling pressured or responsible for closing holes and sinks in the city's budget to keep the city running and with electricity."</s>

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
sna: Vechidiki vokwikwidzana nevatana zvinotyisa kekutanga mumakore gumi pamusika unopa vanhu pekugara muAmerica
mt0: <pad> Young people are taking on the threat of children for the first time in 10 years in the market for housing in the city of New York.</s>

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials people aged 24 to 40 and even baby boomers the over-57 club.
sna: Kuwana imba yekugara rinogona kuva dambudziko kune vechidiki achangopedza zvidzidzo zvake pavanenge votanga kushanda, avo vari kusangana nekumhanyidzirirana  mukuwana pekugara kusati kwaitika mumakore gumi apfuura, kuri kupindirwawo nekukwikwidzwa kusingatarisirwe kubva kune vakazvarwa kuma 1980 zvichienda mberi, neavo vane makore ari pakati pemakumi maviri nemana nemakumi mana, zvichitobatawo avo vari muchikwata chevava nemakore makumi mashanu nemanomwe neanoraudzira.
mt0: <pad> Finding a place to live can be a problem for young graduates who are beginning their career, who are experiencing a rush to find housing that has not seen a rise in the past 10 years, which is also affected by unanticipated competition from 1980s graduates, and those between the ages of 22 and 40, as well as those in the age group of 58 and older.</s>

en: You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances.
sna: Pane vakazvarwa mumakore ekuma 1990 zvichienda mberi vavakutangawo mhuri dzavo vanofanirwa kunge vachibva mudzimba dzekubhadhara mari yekugara mumba mwedzi nemwedzi vachivawo nedzimba dzavo vegani, asi nekuda kwekunetsa kwezvinoshandiswa pakuvaka, izvi zvakatombomiswa kunzvimbo dzakawanda.
mt0: <pad> Some generations of the 1990s and beyond have also begun to start their own vegan families, but due to the shortage of building materials, this has been suspended in many areas.</s>

en: And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent, says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
sna: Saka chaunoona ndechekuti vaya vakazvarwa muna 2000 zvichienda mberi vari kuramba vachigara mudzimba dzekubhadhara mwedzi nemwedzi, anodaro Doug Ressler, mukru anoona nezveruzivo rwekufambiswa kwebasa pa Yardi-Matrix, kambani inoongorora nekuita tsvakurudzo pane zvekutengeswa kwenvzimbo dzekuvaka mabhizimisi nedzimba dzekugara.
mt0: <pad> So what you see is that those born in 2000 and onwards are going to continue to live in rented apartments, says Doug Ressler, senior information manager at Yardi-Matrix, a company that researches and studies the sale of office buildings and housing.</s>

en: It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added.
sna: Izvi hazvisi zve vaya vakabarwa kuma 1980 zvichienda mberi, uye hazvisi zvezera riya rinonzi Generation Z revanhu vari pasi pemakore makumi maviri nemana,tiri kuonawo vechikuru vachipinda mumutsetse wekutsvaga pekugara mudzimba dzemuturidzanwa wemumaguta.
mt0: <pad> This is not for those born in the 1980s, and not for Generation Z of people under the age of 22, we are also seeing elderly people entering the line to find apartments in urban sprawl.</s>

en: Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
sna: Huwandu hwavo hwekushandisa dzimba dzavanobhadhara mari yekugara mwedzi nemwedzi hwanga huchiwanda mumakore mashanu apfuura."
mt0: <pad> The number of their rented apartments has increased over the past five years.</s>

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
sna: Ressler anoti pane zvikonzero zvakasiyana siyana zviri kuita kuti vanhu vati kureyi vasarudze kushandisa dzimba dzavanobhadhara mari yekugara mwedzi nemwedzi.
mt0: <pad> Ressler says there are many reasons why elderly people are choosing to leave their rental homes.</s>

en: They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income, he says.
sna: Vakagara mumba kwenguva yakareba uye vavakuda kuderedza mari yavanoshandisa kuti ingova imwe chete isingashunduke mwedzi nemwedzi, anodaro Ressler.
mt0: <pad> They've been staying in the same place for a long time and are trying to cut down on their monthly bills to just one single-room apartment, Ressler said.</s>

en: "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
sna: "Vanoda kugara mukamusha kevhanhu vari panzvimbo imwe chete , zvakaita semusha unogara vakwegura vakasiya mabasa nedzimwe nzvimbo dzakadaro dzinoita kuti vanzwe kuti vari pakati pevamwe vavanodyidzana nekushamwaridzana navo sevanhu,"
mt0: <pad> "They want to live in a group home, such as a retirement home or similar places that make them feel like they are among others who they interact with and make friends with as people."</s>

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
sna: Musangano wemakambani anotengesa dzimba nekupa vanhu dzimba dzekugara vachibhadhara mwedzi nemwe ye National Association of Realtors (NAR) unoti mari inodiwa yekubhadhara dzimba dziri muzvivakwa zvemituridzanwa yakakwira nezvikamu gumi kubva muzana muna Gunyana 2021 zvichienzaniswa nenguva imwe cheteyo gore rakapera.
mt0: <pad> The National Association of Realtors (NAR) says the cost of rent for condominiums increased by 10 percent in September 2021 compared with the same time last year.</s>

en: It's a hot market.
sna: Musika wedu uri kubhebha.
mt0: <pad> Our music is dying.</s>

en: We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade, says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research.
sna: Hatisati tambowuona uchipisa kudai mumakore gumi adarika, anodaro Gay Cororaton, nyanzvi munezveupfumi uye ari mukuru anoona nezvedzimba netsvakurudzo muNAR.
mt0: <pad> We haven't seen it so hot in the past 10 years, says Gay Cororaton, an expert in economics and the director of the National Institute of Rural Research (NAR).</s>

en: "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
sna: "Kuwedzera kwemari yekubhadhara pekugara mwedzi nemwedzi tichitarisa zvinoitika mugore roga roga kuri pakati pezvikamu zvitatu nezvishanu kubva muzana. asi ikezvino takakuona mari yekubhadharira imba mwedzi nemwedzi ichikwira nezvikamu gumi nechimwe kubva muzana, saka zviri pachena kuti zvavakuitika zavnynya kukwira kudarika zvaisiitika makore akadarika."
mt0: <pad> "The monthly increase in rents over the past year has been between three and five percent. but now we have seen rents rise by 11 percent, so it is clear that the current situation is much higher than the previous years."</s>

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States.
sna: Vanhu vanogara mudzimba dzekubhadhara mwedzi nemwedzi vari panguva yakaoma nekuda kwedenda reCOVID-19 iro rakakanganisa kugadzirwa nekufambiswa kwezvinhu zvinoda kutengwa nevanhu mukurarama kwavo, izvo zvakanonotsa kuvakwa kwedzimba muUnited States.
mt0: <pad> Owners of monthly rental housing are in a difficult time due to the COVID-19 pandemic which has affected production and distribution of consumer goods for their living, which has delayed construction of homes in the United States.</s>

en: Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021.
sna: Pachinzvimbo chekuti zvinhu zvinodiwa kushandiswa zvainge zvichiwanikwa muzvitoro kwemwedzi mitanhatu zvisingashaikwe pakuvaka dzimba dzemhuri imwe neimwe, muna Ndira zvekuvakisa zvakange zvowanikwa kwemwedzi miviri chete.
mt0: <pad> Instead of having enough materials to build six months of homes for every family, in January there were only two months of construction materials available.</s>

en: The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
sna: Kushaikwa kwedzimba kunoreva kuti vanhu vakazvarwa kuma 1990 vava kuva nenguva yakaoma kuti vatenge dzimba dzevanhu vasati vava nevana, iyo yaive tsika yaitevedzerwa munguva yakapfuura.
mt0: <pad> The shortage of housing means that people born in the 1990s are having a hard time buying homes before they have children, which was a tradition that was followed in the past.</s>

en: The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues, Cororaton says.
sna: Chikamu chese chezvekuvaka chakagariswa pasi nekukanganiswa kwakaitika mumakambani anogadzira zvinhu zvekushandisa uye kuzofambiswa kwazvo kuti zviwanikwe nevanozvida, anodaro Cororaton.
mt0: <pad> All construction was grounded by the disruption in manufacturing and will be rushed to make it available to the public, says Cororaton.</s>

en: "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances.
sna: "Zvinhu zvafanirwa kutakurwa nezvikepe zvakange zvisiri kusvika, mutengo wematanda akagadzirirwa kuti avakiswe dzimba wakange uchikwira, kugadzirwa kwezvinhu kwakabva kwaderera, vashandi vakange vasingakwanise kuuya kumabasa, saka kwakazove nekushaikwa zvinobata mikova nemafafitera nemomwe midziyo inoiswa panovakwa imba.
mt0: <pad> "The supplies were not delivered by the ship, the cost of building materials was rising, production was down, workers were unable to come to work, so there was a shortage of door and window brackets and other construction equipment."</s>

en: So, essentially, just a short supply."
sna: Naizvozvo yaive nyaya yekushaikwa kwezvinhu"
mt0: <pad> So it was a matter of shortage.</s>

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
sna: Cororaton anoti zvinhu zvekuvakisa zvakazonyanya kushaikwa nekuti mari zhinji yakange yoiswa mumakambani anovaka dzimba nekuti ndizvo zvaibhadhara, apawo vanhu vakange vatove nedzimba nechekare vakange votsvaga dzimba dzechipiri.
mt0: <pad> The lack of construction materials was worse than the shortage of building materials, according to Cororaton, because much money had been invested in construction companies for profitability, and people who already had homes were looking for second homes.</s>

en: With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes.
sna: Nekuda kwedenda kwakazove nevanoda kutenga dzimba dzepiri, nedzimba dzekunogara panguva yavanenge vakazorora.
mt0: <pad> Because of the depression, there were more people willing to buy second homes, and vacation homes.</s>

en: Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market], she says.
sna: Itsika yekuti dzimba dzekunogara vanhu vari pazororo dzaitora zvikamu zvishanu kubva muzana yedzimba dzose dzaitengwa nekutengeswaanodaro.
mt0: <pad> It was a tradition that holiday homes took up five percent of all new homes sold and bought.</s>

en: "Early this summer they rose to about 8%.
sna: "Tichangopinda muzhizha wegore rino dzimba idzi dzakakwira kusvika pazvikamu zvisere kubva muzana .
mt0: <pad> "Since the start of this year, the number of these houses has risen by eight percent.</s>

en: So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
sna: Saka naizvozvo zvakare kuwanda kwevanhu vaida kutenga dzimba asi pasina kuenzana pakati pevanoda kutenga dzimba nedzimba dzacho dziri kutengeswa kwakaita kuti mitengo yedzimba ikwire, zvikaita kuti dzive dzisiri nyore kuti atenge."
mt0: <pad> So again, the increase in demand for homes but the unevenness between the demand for homes and the available homes caused the price of homes to rise, making them harder to buy.</s>

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South.
sna: Nzvimbo dzine nzvimbo dzirikupisa nekufarirwa nevanhu ike zvino dziri kumavirira nekuchemhembe.
mt0: <pad> The hottest and most popular spots are now in the east and north.</s>

en: More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
sna: Vanhu vari kuda dzimba dzekugara vari kutamira kuDallas nekuHouston mudunhu reTexas, zvhichiteverwa ne Atlanta kudunhu reGeorgia, kozotiwo New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; neWashington mudunhu reD.C., sekutaurwa kwazvakaitwa neNAR.
mt0: <pad> The housing demand is moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta in Georgia, New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington in the District of D.C., according to the NAR.</s>

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
sna: Cororaton anotarisira kuti gore rininouya rinenge riri nani zvishoma asi kushaikwa kwedzimba kuchaenderera mberi kwemakore akati kuti kumberi uko.
mt0: <pad> Cororaton expects a little better next year but the shortage of homes will continue for several years.</s>

en: You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing, says Ressler.
sna: Munoziva zvaisitaurwa makare kuti vanhu vaibva mudzimba dzekubhadhara mwedzi nemwedzi tichipinda mune dzavo, gakava iroro ravakushanduka, anodaro Ressler.
mt0: <pad> You know what used to be said, people would move out of their rented apartments and into ours, that's changed," Ressler said.</s>

en: "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers.
sna: "Nzvimbo yaizipa yaive yevaya musika wekutengesa dzimba uchange uchiunza pundutso nekubhadhara  vakazvagwa mumakore ekuma 1980, asi ava vavakutorerwa chinzvimbo chavo veya vakazvagwa muma 1990 vanonzi maGeneration Z, asi vaya vekuma 1980 vari kugara nguva yakarebesa mudzimba dzekubhadharira mwedzi nemwedzi saka maGeneration Z apindawo mudariro, uye kwozoitawo chikwata chevatana vakazvagwa kuma 1940 kusvika 1965.
mt0: <pad> The most negative was the 1980s home market change bringing comfort and affordability to the 1980s, but they are now replaced by the 1990s Generation Z, but the 1980s are living longer in monthly rented apartments so the Generation Z is also included, and then there is the 1940s to 1965 group.</s>

en: What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
sna: Zvazvinoreva ndezvekuti pava nemusika wezvekutengeswa kwedzimba dzekubhadhara mwedzi nemwedzi ucharamba uchikura."
mt0: <pad> That means that as long as there is a market for rented housing, it will continue to grow.</s>

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children's Immune Systems?
sna: Kurambidzwa Kwekufamba Kwevanhu Kuri kumisa here kukura kwemasojaari mumiviri yevana kuchengetedza nekurwira hutano hwavo?
mt0: <pad> Is restriction of movement stopping the development of cell growth in children's body to protect and fight for their health?</s>

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
sna: Dzimwe nyanzvi dzezvehutano dzaratidza kushushikana zvikuru kuti matanho akatorwa ekudzivirira kupararira kwedenda reCovid-19 zvakaita sekufukidza muromo nejira uye kudzidza kwevana vari kudzimba vachishandisa mapotonjere kunogona kunge kwava kuderedza simba nehuwandu hwemasoja ari mumiviri yevana kuti arwise zvirwere zvinogona kuvabata nekuti izvi zvose zvavakuita kuti vana vasabatwe nezvirwere zvinongosibata vana vechidiki pakukura kwavo.
mt0: <pad> Some health experts have expressed great concern that measures taken to prevent the spread of Covid-19 such as masking the mouth and home-schooling children may be reducing the strength and number of lymphocytes in children's immune systems to fight infections because all these measures are taking place to protect children from infections that can affect young children when they grow up.</s>

en: There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things, says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
sna: Pane zvikonzero zvakawanda zvekuti titende kuti vana vanofanirwa kuregwa vachisangana nezvirwere kuitira kuti masoja emumiviri yavo arambe akasimba achiita mabasa akawanda asingajairirwe nezvirwere, kuitira kuti kana vakasangana nechirwere chinenjodzi huru vane zviri mumasoja avo zvinogona kukurumidza kuyambukira kune chirwere ichi zvigomisidzana nacho zvichirwira vana ava anodaro Sara Sawyer, muzvinafundo munezvekunzvera kushanda nekukura kunoita twumamapazi twuri muropa yemumiviri yevanhu twunoita mitezo yavo ikure uye ichirwisana nezvirwere pa University of Colorado Boulder.
mt0: <pad> There are many reasons why we think children should be exposed to disease so that their immune system can remain strong and do its functions well without being affected by disease, so that if they are exposed to a serious disease they have a healthy immune system that can quickly respond to the disease and fight it," said Sara Sawyer, professor of human blood vessels and lymphocytes at the University of Colorado Boulder.</s>

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
sna: Pavanozvagwa vana vari panjodzi yezvirwere vanowana masoja anodzivirira hutano hwavo kubva kuzvirwere mumukaka wanaamai vavo, zvinova ndizvo zvinovaxhengetedza kusvikira miviri yavo yava kugona kusikawo masoja anovadzivirira kubva kuzvirwere.
mt0: <pad> When babies born with an infectious disease receive the maternal immune system in their milk, the milk is a buffer for them until their body can produce its own immune system.</s>

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.
sna: Haichisi chinhu chinongoitika nemasanga kuti vana vanotanga kuisa zvinhu mukanwa kubva panguva yanongokwanisa kufambisa maoko avo vachisimudza zvinhu.
mt0: <pad> It is not a coincidence that children begin to put things in their mouths as soon as they can move their hands and pick up things.</s>

en: "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
sna: "Vanoita zvinhu izvi nekuti vanenge vachiri kuona kuti munharaunda yavari inechi uye vachivaka simba remauto emumiviri yavo. Ndizvo zvinoitika mukukura nekushanduka kunoita vanhu nemhuka kuti vagone kurarama maringe neshanduko iri kuitiia munharauda dzavanenge vachigara madziri" Sawyer anodaro.
mt0: <pad> "They do this because they are still aware of their environment and building up their immune system. This is the process of growth and evolution that humans and animals undergo to adapt to the changes in their environment," Sawyer said.</s>

en: They are exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
sna: Ipapa vanenge vachitoita kuti miviri yavo isangane nehumwe hutachiona, izvi zvichizoita kuti neimwe nzira inoenzanisira miviri iyi igone kuva nemasoja anprwisana nezvoirwere.
mt0: <pad> They are just making their bodies get infected with another bacterium, which will allow them to have a healthy immune system, which can then be used to fight infections.</s>

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things.

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-30
